section_text_1.eng:
Experts agree that when something bad happens to us or to people who are important to us, the chances it will makes us feel bad depends on three things:


1.    Our Thoughts - How are we explaining what happened? How do we think about ourselves?
2.    Our activity level â€“ Which types of activities are we doing each day? Did we stop doing things that we liked?
3.    Our physical state â€“ How much â€œenergyâ€ do we feel we have? Do we sleep and eat regulary? 

Letâ€™s see the following two stories

section_text_2.eng:
Mina is an experienced 26-year-old facilitator. Being a facilitator is both rewarding and hard. Things got complicated when the funder asked to run groups  with 25 families. Soon Mina began to think that she is not good enough. Every negative thing that happened in the group became a piece of evidence. 
Mina decided to put more effort into her work and stay longer with any parent who needed her. She finished her working days very tired. When she returned home. she didnâ€™t feel like doing anything â€“ just to be alone, and started to cancel meetings with friends and reject their invitations. 
In the beginning, staying at home and simply resting seemed like a good idea, but very quickly it started to be a routine. Eventually, her friends almost stopped inviting her. â€œeven her friends donâ€™t care about me anymoreâ€, she said. 
The more negative things and thoughts Mina experienced, the less active she became. although she went to bed early, she had a hard time sleeping because she was worried about the next day with the group. Because of it, she started every day more exhausted than the day before.

As you can see, both Mina and Joyce coped with a similar situation â€“ work-related distress.

section_text_1.eng:

rows.title: Group facilitation

title.eng: Group facilitation

introduction.eng:
* Good news! Almost every challenge you encounter as a facilitator can be resolved using the facilitation skills you learned during your training. 
* Whatever the challenge is, be positive and encouraging to make everyone feel welcome, valued and supported as equal members of the group. 
* Remind participants of the ground rules you created together, whenever needed. As a group, you set the boundaries to make your group work well! 
* Invite participants to identify their own solutions. You can guide them by asking how a situation makes them feel and by exploring the (possible) consequences of a behaviour or proposed solution. 
* Speak from your heart and in your own words (based on your great HHPP knowledge). This creates the safe space that is needed for everyone to work together well.
You are the expert that is in the best position to solve any challenge that may come!

title.eng: Initial home visit

introduction.eng: The initial home visit will allow you to explore the family needs, and set realistic expectation. It will also enable families to learn more about the programme, ask questions and raise concerns. This will ensure the programme will be an entire family journey.

sections_title.eng: What to do during home visit?

section_text_1.eng:
Try to get as much as information as possible about the household, for example: Who lives in the house?
* Who is the main caregiver?
* How many children and teens are there?
* Who are the main caregivers?
* What is the profession of the caregivers?
* Which challenges they are facing as a family?
* Which support or other programmes are available to them? 
* Which challenges can prevent them from attending the sessions on a weekly basis?

section_text_2.eng:
* It is important that every family set one goal they want to achieve as part of the programme. Help them to set a goal which will be  (1) realistic, (2) positive and (3) actionable
* Realistic â€“ Based on your experience, think if this can be achieved within 9 weeks? If not â€“ help the parent to think about a more modest goal.
* Positive â€“ Help them to rephrase the goal to reflect positiveness ("I want to get more help with house chores") rather than negative (â€˜I want my teen to stop being selfish"")
* Parent-focused - Explore how the parent can contribute to achieving this goal

section_text_3.eng:
Ask participants what goal they would like to achieve during the programme
If the goal is negative - make it positive
Make the goals realisable within 14 weeks and rephrase if necessary:
 * Parent: I want to see my child go to the University Facilitator: "Your goal is to see your child go to university. Our programme is 9 weeks. Will your child be able to go to university in 9 weeks from now? Is there a quicker goal that can help your child go to university? * Parent: Yes, I can help my child so they improve their marks in school this semester.â€ Facilitator: Great! So your goal can be "getting ideas on how to help my child to improve his marks in school this semester"

section_text_4.eng:

title.eng: How to manage expectations

introduction.eng: Parents will come with various expectations from the group and from you as a facilitator. Unrealistic expectations can lead to frustration and leaving the group, so it is important to identify and address them as soon as possible. Here is how.

section_text_1.eng:
* Other programmes may have given participants something in the past (for example snacks or transport), so now participants may expect that we do the same. Especially if participants have attended other services offered by your organisation, this may raise expectations.
* Some questions in the pre-post survey may raise expectations among participants that the programme will provide material support (like â€œhow many meals did you miss in the last weekâ€).
Please make sure to explain the purposes of the survey clearly: Access Recruitment Steps and look for the dropdown menu called " Step 3: Introduce survey & manage expectations 
* Families may have other ideas about the programme that may keep them from participating or may make them drop out. Common misperceptions that you may need to address include: - "This programme is for bad parents and/or bad children" - "This programme is only for a specific group of parents or children (e.g orphans) - "This programme is only for female caregivers".

section_text_2.eng:
* Differentiate the programme
It is important to explain that HHPP is a different programme from previous programmes that participants may have attended. Be clear that participants will not get material incentives when joining HHPP and emphasise the unique value that HHPP offers (without being negative about other programmes).
You cannot control what others people or organisations may be saying to participants before the start of the programme. What you CAN control is what you share during home visits and group sessions.
* Be confident of value of programme
Be confident that you are offering something that will add value to families. Remember, HHPPâ€™s lifelong impact on parents, teens and families will always be appreciated more in the end than temporary material incentives.
[Voice recording of testimonial: Parents and teens were still attending group sessions on session 10, because they saw that the impact on their families was worth more than the Hungry Lion they were getting from the other programme â€“ Chris, Livingstone]  

* Help participants feel ownership of the group
Empower your group by inviting participants to come up with their own ideas rather than presenting answers or solutions. 
When participants feel this is â€˜theirâ€™ group, they will become less dependent on you and your organisation for answers or resources. The group will start supporting each other and may even be able to put resources together for activities like the graduation ceremony. 
* Create space for concerns
Please give caregivers lots of space to ask any questions they may have and address those clearly, both during recruitment and throughout the programme. By building a good relationship with each participant, they will feel free to share any concerns with you as they may come up and you may be able to prevent participants from dropping out.  
* Be aware of other programmes
Your organisation, or other organisations, may be offering other programmes in the communities where you work. Know about these programmes, so you know what expectations or ideas these programmes may have raised about HHPP and can be ready to address these.

rows.title: Home visits & phone calls

title.eng: Home visits & phone calls

introduction.eng:
* Participants may miss a session or need additional support for different reasons. Whatever the reason is, it is important that they are caught up to help them build their skills and stay involved in the programme.
* Building the skills of parents is the first focus of HHPP, as this creates healthy supportive family environments for teens. For follow-ups, it is therefore most important that the **parent is present**. Their teen(s) and other family members can also join the visit/call if they are available.

sections_title.eng: How to make follow-ups a success:

section_text_1.eng: Brainstorm ideas with your participants by asking â€˜Some of our group have missed this session, what can we do to get everyone updated?â€™. When ideas and suggested dates/times come from participants it is more likely that the solution will work well for them and that they will follow through.

section_text_2.eng:
* In HHPP, each participant is paired with a â€˜buddyâ€™. 
* A buddy can share with a participant what they learned in the session. Even if you will still do a home visit afterwards, an update by the buddy will shorten the time you need for that home visit as you are only filling in the gaps.
* To prevent the same person from missing another session, you can encourage the buddy to remind the participant of the upcoming session.

section_title_3.eng: Do a joint home visit catch-up

section_text_3.eng: When multiple participants have missed a session, you can invite them to come for a joint catch-up session at one of their homes. This is particularly helpful when participants stay closer together.

section_title_4.eng: Do a phone call or WhatsApp call

section_text_4.eng:
* When participants have phones, you can give them a call to catch them up on a session missed.
* If they have a smart phone with WhatsApp, you can catch them up via a WhatsApp call (or even a conference call so multiple participants can join one catch-up).

section_text_5.eng: * It can be hard to find parents or teenagers at home at times that work well for them and yourself. You can explore if you can visit them at their school or work place (office, farm land, etc.).

title.eng: Graduation ceremony

introduction.eng: The goal of the session is to show parents and teens how to praise and appreciate each other. While parents become more effective at giving specific, positive, and realistic instructions, teens learn how to communicate their needs and wants in a clear and calm way.

section_text_1.eng:
* Praise the behaviour you want to see in your parent/teen
* Appreciate your parent/teen for the positive things that s/he does
* Be specific, immediate, and enthusiastic when you praise your parent/teen
* Your parent/teen will feel better about him/herself when you praise him/her
* Instructions should be positive, specific, and realistic and given in a calm voice
* Praise your teen when s/he follows your instruction
* Explain what you want to your parent/teen in a clear and calm way
* Praise yourself!

introduction.eng: In this session parents and teens learn how to become more aware of their own emotions, respond effectively and communicate about their emotions.

* Communicating about emotions improved relationships. Communicating about emotions helps us understand each other better so we can learn how to support each other

rows.title: Session 1 - common challenges for parents  and how to solve them

title.eng: Session 1 - common challenges for parents  and how to solve them

introduction.eng: Parents didnâ€™t have time for 1on1? Didnâ€™t feel comfortable doing the activities? Struggle with scheduling 1on1 time for multiple teens?

section_title_1.eng: I did not have enough time

section_text_1.eng:
* It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. 

* Think of a time each day that you could spare 5 minutes. You can even make household chores into a game to do together

section_title_2.eng: My teen did not want to spend time with me

section_text_2.eng:
* Teens often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. 

* You could watch or play on the gadget with them. 

* Caring about their interests is a great start!

* Once you begin spending time together you can suggest another activity.

section_title_3.eng: My teen wanted to do things I felt uncomfortable about

section_text_3.eng:
* If your teen wants to do things that are too difficult for you to do, you could watch them.  

* You could describe what they are doing like a sports announcer.

* Praise them while they do it!

section_title_4.eng: "My teen chose a competitive activity. I won and then they got angry"

section_text_4.eng:
Competitive games can be hard for teens (and adults!) if they donâ€™t like losing. 

When they have calmed down, talk with your teen about what winning well and losing well might look like.

Suggest other activities that you can do to work together instead of against each other.

section_title_5.eng: All my children wanted One-on-one Time at the same time

section_text_5.eng:
It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each child when you have more than one child. 

If possible, you can ask an adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one teen.

Think of when it would be easier to spend One-on-One time with each child. Perhaps later in the evening with your teen, after the others have gone to sleep.

introduction.eng: Parent forgot to praise? Teen felt strange when praised? Parent used negative and not positive instructions? Here are some solutions to these frequent challanges

section_title_1.eng: I forgot to praise my teen

section_text_1.eng:
* It can sometimes be hard to remember to praise our teens. 

* Next time you spend one-on-one time with your teen, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. 

* You can even say, â€œThank you for spending time with me!â€.

section_title_2.eng: My teen did not like it

section_text_2.eng:
* It happens - just be patient. 

* Make sure to keep spending time with your teen, so they will value your opinion more and more. 
* When your praise is genuine, you will see the benefits soon!

section_title_3.eng: My teen was surprised and felt suspicious

section_text_3.eng:
* Remember, it takes some time for your teen to get used to seeing you praise them. 

* The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!

section_title_4.eng: Myâ€¯teenagerâ€¯did not want to follow the instruction

section_text_4.eng:
* Our children need time to learn to follow instructions. 

* Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!

section_title_5.eng: I gave a negative instead of a positive instruction

section_text_5.eng:
* It takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions â€“ itâ€™s really worth trying again! 

* Think about the behaviour you would love to see your teen do more and think of positive ways to give that instruction!

section_title_6.eng: I shouted at myâ€¯teenâ€¯when they behaved negatively, instead of giving them a positive instruction for what theyâ€¯shouldâ€¯do.

section_text_6.eng:
* It is difficult to come up with instructions while we are still angry. 

* Try and find a time when you are calm to introduce a positive instruction to your teen.

* In the next session, we will ll talk more aboutâ€¯how we can manage our emotions!

introduction.eng: Teen felt uncomfortable when parent shared emotions? Parent struggle with sharing? Here is what to say

section_title_1.eng: "Iâ€™m afraid my teen might think I am weak for sharing my emotions."

section_text_1.eng:
* Sharing your emotions sets an important example for your teen - even more when sharing difficult emotions! 

* It makes everyone in the family stronger, because it means you can understand and support each other better.

section_title_2.eng: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings.

section_text_2.eng:
* Being specific is not rude or insensitive - it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. 

* Feelings like anger and stress are part of our lives. 

* All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is handle our emotions well by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

section_title_3.eng: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings.

section_text_3.eng:
* Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. 

* Give yourselves some time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. 

* Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!

section_title_4.eng: When I shared my emotions, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable.

section_text_4.eng:
* Sharing emotions helps your teen to be aware and learn to do the same. 

* You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. Itâ€™s up to you! 

* You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, â€œI am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonightâ€

section_title_5.eng: I was too stressed or angry to try sharing my emotions â€“ I prefer to be alone when I feel like that.

section_text_5.eng:
* Itâ€™s okay to not want to share at that time. 

* Find some time to explain later, when you feel calmer, so that everyone can understand.
